full_text: Case 1:20-cr-00330-PAE Document 782 Filed 01/15/25 Page 121 of 158 121 LBAGmax4 Rocchio - Cross 1 A. Yes, many of the studies specifically look at disclosure that is delayed, as in not occurring at the time of the abuse. 2 And then look at what are those rates at various points in time, so it could be a week later, it could be a month later, 3 it could be a year later or five years later. 4 Q. So those are all variables in this idea of when disclosure occurs; right? 5 A. They are variables in the dynamics of the delay. They are all examples of delayed disclosure at various points in time. 6 Because delayed disclosure refers to disclosure at some point after the incident that's being disclosed. 7 Q. I want to ask you some questions about memory now, which is another area of your opinion. 8 You agree with me that memory is a complex topic? 9 A. I do. 10 Q. Memory is generally regarded as the mental registration, retention and recollection of past experiences, sensations or thoughts; would you agree with that? 11 A. I would. 12 Q. And there are a number of parts of the brain that work in connection to form memories; would you agree with that? 13 A. I would. 14 Q. Do you know what those parts are? 15 A. I'm not an expert on neuroscience, so I would not -- I could certainly go and review the literature and get back to 16 SOUTHERN DISTRICT REPORTERS, P.C. (212) 805-0300 DOJ-OGR-00014997
